Hi

>> Briefly the problem is two "very simple" Java bean classes (A and 
>> B).  Class A is really simple: a constructor with a number of 
>> arguments and a host of accessor methods for retrieving this 
>> (member) data.

> This sounds like a data class... why does it exist if it has no behaviour?

It exists because I did not want duplicate code within B, so I extraced the
common code out (which seemed reasonable to me at the time).  Also because
these little A objects are used elsewhere it made sense for them not to be
in the transport data type which only has a single specific purpose (to
serialise data off the wire).

Also we have a lot of code built to an inhouse protocol talking to an
inhouse server.  The current chosen method of doing this (and I'm not here
to debate the rights and wrongs of that method) is via serialisation of
protocol data types across the wire.  My application code cares not how
these things are created, but that it can use them as it wishes (usually to
construct it's own model of how it sees the world).

> This is something that's been really pissing me off about Java..
> institutionalization of crappy design practices.

Thank you for your polite phrasing - I simply have to play with what I am
given.  Please don;t get carried away with my use of the words Java Beans, I
used them in this context because it explained the "simplicity" of the
classes in question rather nicely.  My actual question/query has nothing to
do with Java Beans or their use.  

My question was about interdependencies within classes being tested.  Being
(still) reasonably new to this area I thought it was worth clarification,
especially when a lot of posts on this list (and within various TDD/Unit
Testing stuff I've read) talk alot about mocking out components so the
behaviours under test become more self contained.

In my original question, I have (in my example) two classes on totally self
contained and can be tested/re-implemented ad infinitum in its own little
world.  My query comes about when I want to test/develop the other class
that contains an instance of the former.  Now my second class (B) is
inextrably coupled to (A) so I was questioning whether anybody (with more
experience than I) had any suggestions about how to remove this dependency,
or whether I was/am worrying about it too much.

In my current scenario the dependency is not such an issue, however Iwould
like to pick up good practices so that when I come to a more complex version
of the same problem I can then make an informed judgement as to what to do.

>> here comes the dependency.  Class B contains a number of (two) class
>> A instances.  The raw data is read within readExternal and then used
>> to construct the instances of A.  Class B provides a couple of 
>> accessors to retrieve those A instances.
>> 
>> Within my unit test for B's Externalizable implementation is to 
>> check that what I pass in on the InputStream results in the B 
>> instance I expect.  But B contains two As so I appear to have two 
>> points of failure:  A.equals might fail which would result in the 
>> tests for both A and B failing.

> I don't see a problem.  You have tests for A.  You have tests for B. 
> The fact that B involves A is a non issue.  If A breaks, it's tests
> will fail... and yes, so will B's.. so what.  If A's tests fail, that
> indicates that A is broken... don't worry that B's tests will fail
> since A is broken... go fix A.  All the tests should pass again.

As outlined previously - I have no "problem", I have tests for both class A
and class B, I was simply quering whether the dependency was sensible.  I
don't spend much time worrying about whether B fails as a consequence of A.

Thank you for your time
Jonathan
